Well, 20 percent of our electricity is generated by nuclear power plants.

But they all are very similar in the way they produce electricity.

Should we presume that we're talking about the ones in California?
Well, the ones in California are certainly more likely to have an earthquake and a larger earthquake than we would have throughout the country.
But every nuclear power plant in the United States is protected against a certain level of earthquake that's appropriate to the region in which they are built.

So although the ones in California would have larger earthquakes, they're designed basis is more robust, so that you would not expect to have a higher likelihood of a core meltdown accident, as a result of an earthquake that exceeded the design basis for California.

Could there be an exceptional earthquake at some low probability in the United States, relative to what the design basis is?
I think that it certainly is possible that that's true.

But I think you also have to look and see that - it certainly appears that despite the very large earthquake there, and relative to its design basis, as far as the shaking element of is concerned, it certainly appears that the plants had enough margin beyond what we call a Safe Shutdown Earthquake, that they really accommodated that.
And the thing that got them was the size of the tsunami.

And so I would think that if anybody is going to be looking at anything closely, as a result of this, it will be the question of for those plants that are on oceans: Has there been adequate design margin been provided for tsunamis?
